instruction: What kinds of spectrum were used in the related research to identify the category and proportion of adulterated oil in Camellia oil (CAO)?
Output: The research used excitation-emission matrix fluorescence (EEMF) spectra to analyze the vegetable oil samples, specifically Camellia oil (CAO).

instruction: What spectral feature processing methods were used in the related research to identify the category and proportion of adulterated oil in Camellia oil (CAO)?
Output: Chemometrics method and machine learning methods, specifically convolutional neural network (CNN) and partial least squares regression, were used to process spectral features in the related research to identify the category and proportion of adulterated oil in Camellia oil (CAO).

instruction: What metric was chosen to evaluate the performance of the models in the related research to identify the category and proportion of adulterated oil in Camellia oil (CAO), and how far can this metric go?
Output: The metric chosen to evaluate the performance of the models in the related research was classification accuracy. The classification accuracy was reported to be 95.8% for identifying the oil species adulterated in CAO mixtures and 92.2% for quantifying the fraud of CAO proportion in blended oil. This metric measures the percentage of correctly classified samples out of the total samples evaluated. It indicates how well the models were able to accurately identify and quantify the adulterated oil in CAO.

instruction: How were the machine learning models used in the related research on developing an intelligent analysis method to determine the category and proportion of adulterated oil in Camellia oil (CAO) in order to address the issue of adulteration?
Output:
In the related research, the machine learning models were used to develop authenticity identification models and quantitative models for analyzing adulterated oil in Camellia oil (CAO).

For authenticity identification, four machine learning methods were employed. The researchers used the excitation-emission matrix fluorescence (EEMF) spectra of 933 vegetable oil samples, including both authentic and adulterated oils. These spectra were characterized using a chemometric method to extract chemically meaningful information. The machine learning models were then trained on these spectra to discriminate between different oil species that were adulterated in CAO mixtures. The goal was to accurately identify the category of adulterated oil present in CAO.

For quantitative analysis, the researchers aimed to determine the proportion of adulterated oil in blended oil samples. They established quantitative models using the EEMF fingerprints and machine learning techniques. These models were trained to estimate the fraud of CAO proportion in the blended oil samples. The objective was to provide accurate and intelligent analysis to determine the proportion of adulterated oil in CAO.

The results of the research showed that a specially constructed Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) model performed optimally in evaluating unseen real-world samples. It achieved a classification accuracy of 95.8% for authenticity identification

instruction: Can the combination of EEMF fingerprints and machine learning methods be considered superior to traditional methods in detecting the authenticity of Camellia oil (CAO), based on the classification accuracy and mean-absolute quantitative errors achieved in the related research?
Output: Yes, based on the results of the related research, the combination of EEMF fingerprints and machine learning methods can be considered superior to traditional methods in detecting the authenticity of Camellia oil (CAO). The research showed that the specially constructed CNN achieved a classification accuracy of 95.8% and 92.2% for unseen real-world samples. Additionally, the mean-absolute quantitative errors ranged between 2.6 and 6.7%. These results indicate that the combination of EEMF fingerprints and machine learning methods provides intelligent and accurate analysis for authenticity detection of CAO, surpassing traditional methods.
